title: Friday briefing: Is this the pathway to Brexit?
text:
Top story: Irish leader to report to EU on progress

Good morning briefers. I’m Martin Farrer, bringing you the top stories from home and abroad this Friday morning.

Stephen Barclay, the Brexit secretary, will meet EU’s top negotiator, Michel Barnier, in Brussels this morning after talks between Boris Johnson and Leo Varadkar, the Irish taoiseach, provided renewed hope of a Brexit deal. The two leaders hinted at a “pathway” to an agreement when they emerged from their country house meeting in Cheshire with an upbeat message that took European bureaucrats by surprise. Varadkar will also report to Brussels on the meeting, and Barnier will assess whether sufficient progress has been made for in-depth talks to start before next Thursday’s crunch summit in Brussels. Both Varadkar and Johnson agreed there was enough for substantive talks, although the taoiseach warned there was “many a slip between cup and lip”. Downing Street refused to say if Johnson had conceded ground on the Irish border issue – potentially causing conflict with hardliners in his ranks – and EU officials were also reluctant to discuss details. One EU official predicted a week of no sleep for negotiating teams but described the chances of a deal as “ambitious”.

The pound soared on the news and this morning’s papers are full of optimism. Back in Westminster, pro-remain MPs said they would test the water for a second referendum when parliament sits for the so-called “super Saturday” next weekend.

US red lines – The Trump administration has tried to clarify its policy towards Turkey’s invasion of northern Syria by setting out red lines that Ankara must not cross. As the death toll from the bombardment of communities along the Turkish-Syrian border continued to mount, a senior official said the US would not tolerate any suggestion of ethnic cleansing in the heavily Kurdish area, or “indiscriminate artillery, air and other fire directed at civilian population”. Despite the widespread view that Donald Trump sanctioned the Turkish invasion, the official condemned the military action. Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdoğan earlier pushed back against criticism by threatening to send millions of Syrian refugees currently living in Turkey towards the EU. Our Middle East correspondent, Martin Chulov, reports from the city of Qamishli on the bitter mood among Kurds fleeing the fighting. “After giving 5,000 martyrs, this is how they respond to our sacrifice,” one said. And Bethan McKernan hears the view from the other side where Turks fear the onset of war.

At home, Trump saw two Soviet-born American associates of his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, charged with funneling foreign money into his election campaign. But at a rally in Minnesota, the president tried to weaponise the impeachment inquiry launched against him by Democrats, lashing out at Joe Biden as the crowd chanted “Lock him up!”.

BBC under pressure – Competition from streaming services such as Netflix will place increasing pressure on the BBC’s finances as the cost of making programmes goes up and younger viewers see no need to pay the licence fee. A report by the Commons culture committee points to data showing that people under-34 spend on average more than twice as much time each day watching YouTube than they do BBC 1, BBC2, ITV 1, Channel 4 and Channel 5 combined. But the MPs also called on the government to ensure that all over-75s receive a free licence.

Social housing threat – Councils say the government has “trashed” plans to build more social housing across the country after it raised the cost of Treasury loans. Local leaders say the one percentage point increase on public works loan board (PWLB) finance, which was imposed “out of the blue” this week, could delay or scupper housebuilding and regeneration schemes. Sharon Taylor, the leader of Stevenage council, says it is “another big blow for local government finance”.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Stormzy, centre back row, with some students starting at Cambridge University. Photograph: Stormzy

Gown with the kids – A record number of black British students are studying at Cambridge University thanks in part to a scholarship scheme set up by the musician Stormzy. Cambridge say 91 black British students have started as undergraduates this year, up nearly 50% on last October. Stormzy, a grime music star, announced that he was setting up two scholarships and is also paying for the tuition fees and living expenses of two more.

Selfie alarm – Police in Japan have revealed an extraordinary case in which a pop star was allegedly attacked by a stalker who tracked her down by analysing details reflected in her eyes in selfies posted on social media. In one image, he deciphered a train sign from which he located her local station. He then lay in wait for her one night in September and assaulted her.

Today in Focus podcast: the problem of diplomatic immunity

Harry Dunn died in a collision in August with a car allegedly being driven by the wife of a US diplomat, who left the UK soon after under the rules of diplomatic immunity. Patrick Wintour looks at what might happen next. And author Jonathan Safran Foer on changing the way we eat to avoid climate catastrophe.

Lunchtime read: Naomie Harris, from Moonlight to action hero

After a career of eye-catching supporting roles such as in Moonlight, the Bond films and Pirates of the Caribbean, Naomie Harris plays the lead as a New Orleans cop in her new film Black and Blue. The British star says her intense approach to her work (after Moonlight she was “completely burned out” and wanted to open a nail salon) meant she always preferred playing second fiddle. But supporting roles might a thing of the past for the 43-year-old who tells Cath Clarke about growing up in Finsbury Park, the time she was groped by “a huge star”, how Phoebe Waller-Bridge was on call to sex up the latest Bond script and playing a gun-toting cop – “I was like: ‘Oh my gosh, I am an action hero in this movie. This is not how I envisioned my career at all’.”

Sport

An ill wind may be blowing for some at the Rugby World Cup but for Eddie Jones and England life is suddenly unexpectedly calm as they face a free weekend at the seaside in Japan. Scotland’s coach, Gregor Townsend, believes his side will not be denied a last-eight chance but the weather and a reluctance to relocate or postpone Sunday’s game against Japan suggest otherwise. Gareth Southgate has moved to smooth relations with Bulgaria before the Euro 2020 qualifier on Monday after he and members of the England squad were accused of making “offensive” and “derogatory” remarks. Kieffer Moore, a former lifeguard, saved Wales’ Euro 2020 qualification hopes from drifting into troubled waters with a goal that spared them a crushing defeat in Slovakia.

Simone Biles continued to stake her claim as one of the most dominant athletes of her generation as she bulldozed all competition to win her fifth world championships individual all‑around gold medal in Stuttgart. And Chris Silverwood has preached a return to the old-fashioned values of batting time and relentlessness with the ball as the new England men’s coach outlined his vision of a Test team who can regain the Ashes in two years’ time.

Business

The entrepreneur who saved HMV from administration earlier this year is set to open a huge new store in Birmingham city centre under the venerable old brand. The supermarket-sized outlet will stock 80,000 CDs and 25,000 vinyl albums in a bold expansion that Doug Putnam thinks can defy slumping physical sales.

Businesses in the US are lamenting the prospect of tariffs on British imports such as Jammie Dodgers, Scottish shortbread, clotted cream and Irish bacon. Sean Kavanagh-Dowsett, co-owner of the Manhattan restaurant Tea & Sympathy, says: “It’s going to impact us, and as always it’s going to get passed on to customers.” The pound has held on to its Brexit-related gains overnight to sit at $1.244 and €1.129, while the FTSE100 looks like opening down 0.5%.

The papers

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: The Guardian

Brexit dominates most the front pages. The Guardian splash says “Johnson and Varadkar: ‘We can see a pathway to possible Brexit deal’”, while the Times is on the same wavelength with “Britain and Ireland on ‘pathway to agreement’”, as is the Telegraph with “Deal can be done by Oct 31, say Irish”. The FT are also on the same track with “Johnson and Varadkar see Brexit deal ‘pathway’ as talks shift mood”. The Scotsman agrees that “Johnson and Varadkar can ‘see pathway’ to Brexit deal”. The Mail chances its arm a bit more and asks “Dare we dream of a deal?”, while the Express is also in a questioning mood with “Has Boris only gone and done it?”. The Metro says “Irish eyes are smiling” and the i says “‘Pathway to a deal in sight’”.

The Sun leads with the Rooney/Vardy bust-up – “Becky’s wagony” – and the Mirror diverges from Brexit with Rod Stewart’s wife shedding “Tears for my brave Rod”.
